I will say that one night I was just exhausted, and went to my room at 11:30 pm. Fell asleep and nothing woke me till the morning, so... I guess if you're tired enough, even the light show won't keep you awake. LOL. They do have the heavy drapes that keep out light if you want it that way. I even filmed some of a light show from that window. It is a unique vantage point on the whole Fremont Street thing.Food at the Bay City Diner is inexpensive, and delicious. Service is good, and is usually pretty fast. The Deli sandwiches are great as well, and who doesn't know about the Shrimp Cocktails for 99c here! They are famous since 1957! This is the oldest casino/hotel in Las Vegas, and... I hope it sticks around for a lot longer. I had luck here gambling also~! Fun slots and excellent blackjack rules.I highly recommend this hotel... The only thing that I have to say that takes away from it is that... I wasn't happy that the iron and hair dryer could only be checked out for one hour at a time. I did mention that they should put this on their website so that people are aware of it. Thats why I'm putting it here. It won't stop me from going back.. but it will make it where I can make arrangements on my own.

Jun 7 2009 	I liked it. Clean Friendly and well worth $19.06 a night!	I booked May 31 to June 5 at the Golden Gate. Because I wasn't sure I'd like it, I also booked a couple of nights at the Golden Nugget. After one night at GG, I cancelled that other reservation.I arrived at the GG early on a Sunday. They did not have anything ready facing Fremont, so I left my belongings with the front desk and went out to wander Fremont Street. When I came back, it was still early and they only had smoking rooms available so far. The head housekeeper told me that since the rooms were newly renovated, I would not smell anything. And she was right. I had room #207 - second floor facing Fremont. It was small, but perfect for one person who wasn't going to spend a lot of time in the room anyway. I liked the way it was decorated, too. There was a small closet, but a large dresser with plenty of room for clothes. The room had a flat-screen TV and a coffee maker (with coffee, cups & etc). There was also a clock radio with an iPod dock. I've read some reviews that say paper-thin walls, but no one complained when I played my music, so they couldn't have been that bad.The front desk has irons and hair dryers available. If the place is busy, they only let you have them for a certain amount of time, but I opted for wet hair and wrinkled clothes anyway.The bathroom is kind of dated, but clean. I'm not a fan of separate hot and cold water knobs, but the old fashioned style added to the ambiance. I never did seem to get the shower water temperature just right, but I didn't get burned, so that's all that counts.I would have like a more comfortable bed, but at $19.06/night we're not talking Wynn quality mattresses. The only thing I didn't like was that, being short, I couldn't get close to the bathroom mirror to apply makeup. I had to use the large mirror on the wall by the bed, but the lighting in the room was kind of dim and not useful for that purpose. So they could use some of those swing-out makeup mirrors or brighter lighting near the mirror.Overall, I liked my stay at the Golden Gate. I wouldn't hesitate to stay again. Everyone I came in contact with that worked there was super helpful and friendly. And Valet was fast and friendly, too. They have one small lot with Valet and you never wait more than a minute for your car.(I ate downstairs at the Bay City Diner and the food & service was good both times)

Jun 7 2009 	Great place to party!	We reserved a room for $20 solely for the purpose to have a place to hang out between light shows downtown. We were given a room overlooking Fremont, which was exactly what we wanted. We opened both windows and enjoyed the music and people watching from the street. The room was very small, but clean and updated. The beds were very comfy although we didn't spend the night. We just enjoyed drinks and the views with two other couples. The hotel & casino were clean and everyone was nice.

Jun 1 2009 	Very old and smelt...front desk and 'valet' poor service	My stay was overall poor. When we arrived at the hotel, I asked valet where can we park? He tried to direct me to the self-serve parking down the street. In my head was why do I have to park down the street when I can park here? Did he feel he would not be receiving a tip??? We pulled up into 'valet' and let him park our car. We had to hurry and get all our bags out since he just stood there standing there demanding we get everything out. At check-in, the first thing said was I need your photo id from both and a valid credit card. Barely a 'hi' or even a fake courteous gesture given. I tried to ignore that as well. When we got our keys, we went through the smelly hallways on 2nd floor and into the far corner. Low and behold, our room as previous people have communicated in their reviews, tiniest room, but clean. We asked for a quieter room and 2 beds, got completely opposite. I phoned my sister long distance to ask her to check with expedia online to see if there were room availabilities for this hotel, and she said she was able to book for the same night. When I went back downstairs to ask for an alternate room, we were told they were all sold out for the night. When I mentioned that if I am available to still book, does that not mean there are rooms available? Alex kept mentioning, rooms are all sold. That was the second time in the same night, on first impression, most of the staff are willing to re-direct you to 'find your own way around'. Very unhelpful both valet & staff. Front desk and valet service are classified as providing customer service for their customers. Certainly, this hotel is rated a 2-star for a reason. Not only for their small and barely updated room, but as a first and last impression -- poor service. Also to note, this hotel does not have room service. When we phoned in to get 2 extra towels. Housekeeping is only open from 7am-3pm! If you want towels, go downstairs yourself! Also can't describe this hotels style besides poor and NOT incredible staff. Poor impression. Would NOT recommend anyone for even 1 night merely because of the cheaper rate.

May 27 2009 	A very nice stay at the Golden Gate Hotel/Casino.	I stayed at the Golden Gate for five nights--May 15 through May 19. The rooms have been recently refurbished and IMO look very nice. The room I had (# 252) was small but very good for a solo guest. The room faced the Plaza and was quiet. The room was clean, the bed was very comfortable, the water was hot and cold as needed, the television was a new flat screen with limited channels but OK with me, and the room was cleaned every day.I enjoyed my stay at the Golden Gate and took advantage of the diner and the great sandwiches and shrimp cocktails at the snack bar. I played slots for many hours with no big wins but several small ones. The drink service while playing slots was excellent. I would certainly stay again.

May 18 2009 	I will stay here again	First time staying, and i will be booking again here in October. I prefer to spend less money on a room, and more of it gambling.The room was on the small side, but very nice and clean. The bathroom was small and somewhat outdated, but again clean. The shower head was new, and just about came down from the ceiling, so being 6'3, i could stand directly under it. I did not experience the "no hot water" issue, but then again, i showered in the afternoon, and had ample hot water. My room was cleaned each day.I orignally booked a smoking room, as there were no non smoking rooms available. I contacted the hotel a few times prior to my visit ,about changing rooms, and they said there were non available. I get there to checkin late at night, and they had switched me to a non smoking room.The noise was not that bad, but i also had a room not directly on freemont street.With the hotel only being 4 stories, there was never an issue with waiting for an elevator.

Apr 23 2009 	Very Cozy	After finding out Golden Gate had remodeled their rooms, I was really excited to stay here. We, four women/one room, stayed here 6 nights. I found the casino and hotel to be very cozy. The rooms are newly redone, they look really nice and are clean. Pillow top beds, which were very comfortable. The pillows were decent. Flat screen TV and a coffee maker.Our first room was one of the smaller rooms but we figured we would manage. Our room, with the windows that totally opened out, overlooked Fremont Street which I really liked. The bathroom had a tub with shower and was small. It also had a small closet. When we were going out the next morning, one of the rooms was being cleaned and was bigger. My mom went down to see if we could move to it, it was open, so we did. This room had three windows overlooking Fremont Street. The closet was deeper than the previous room. This bathroom had a tiled shower, there is a picture posted of it. No shower door, just an opening. Kind of neat in a way. They really need to redo these bathrooms. Or if anything redo the caulking around the sink area, it didn't look very clean. The grout around the tiles looked a bit dirty. But, we were not in the bathrooms a whole lot so it wasn't an issue, even with the four of us getting ready in the mornings. We showered and then did makeup out in the room. There is a very large mirror hung on the wall. We did not have the cold water issue as others have had. We showered anywhere from 6:30am to 8:00am. In the middle of our stay they installed a new very large shower head. It was great.I thought the rooms were dark which I didn't mind but some might. The door had about a two inch gap on the bottom but we didn't hear a lot of noise from the hall. Now for the noise from Fremont Street. We all just knew, we would not be going to sleep before the last show. The room was very noisy from the Freemont light show, it was very very loud. But I loved hanging out the window watching it.The motorcycle cage was just under our window, had a good view but very loud as well. There was also a man with a microphone coming over the speakers doing something underneath our windows, never did check to see what. He continued for maybe 30 minutes after the last light show. But after everything settled down, I don't recall much noise. Could be I was just really tired.The noise was like there were no windows at all. If they could replace these, it would be great.Housekeeping after learning there was four of us, gave us extra soaps and shampoos. Even with the noise and the bathroom, I loved our room.We all love the shrimp cocktails here. With your players card they are only 99cents, available at the shrimp bar. We ate in the Bay City Diner, I think the food is good. We too received the money credits on our cards daily, we only received $5 a day. I had a little luck in the casino. It was nice after a day of going out to other casinos to come back to this tiny one and gamble a bit ant then the rooms aren't that far away and not a long walk down a hall to your room. If you want something fancy and plush, this is not the place. I'm not sure many people will tolerate the noise in the rooms.I loved it here. And the price could not be beat.

Apr 20 2009 	Better than you'd expect for $19	First off, if you are considering the Golden Gate, please understand that you are not going to get 4-star accomodations for $19.06. As long as you have reasonable expectations, you will probably not be disappointed. My wife and I booked a room there for Saturday, April 11th at their promotional rate of $19.06. This, for a Saturday night, was a ridiculous deal. Since they only have 100 or so rooms, check-in was a breeze. We received our room in the "old" section of the hotel, which meant that the room was extremely small. That was OK with us. We didn't choose the Golden Gate for the amenities, after all. The room was very clean and looked nice with its art-deco motif. There were framed photos of Frank Sinatra and Louis Armstrong on the walls, which I thought was cool. It also had a sweet flat-screen TV. The bathroom was, again, small but functional with one exception. As a previous reviewer noted, there was no hot water in the morning. This was, admittedly, frustrating but I was willing to overlook it for the price. A cold shower helped to work me out of my hangover-induced haze anyway.When we asked at the front desk about the water, we were told that since the GG is an old hotel (the oldest in Vegas), the hot water isn't as readily available in the mornings and if you shower in the afternoon, it should be at an acceptable temperature. Rather ridiculous but, again, $19. One other cool thing about our room was that it had windows that opened. And not just a crack - fully open, both windows. That's a rarity in Vegas. All in all, I thought the Golden Gate was a great value. If you're going to gamble at all, I highly recommend signing up for their players club. My wife and I both did and we received $20 and $25 each in free play EVERY DAY FOR A WEEK!!!!! This was incredible news to us, as we had played almost nothing through their machines. We were only downtown for the one night but could have gotten over $300 in free play if we played there every day. This was not well-publicized, however. I only found out about it by accident when my card wouldn't work and I had to go to the player's club desk to get another one. Apparently every player gets a random bonus added to their account. Sweet!

Apr 13 2009 	Good budget option for Downtown Las Vegas	When online travel sites started promoting killer Vegas deals in March, we decided to take an off-budget, Easter weekend getaway. In prior trips to vegas, we would stay on/near the strip, and decided to give Downtown a try this time (closer to Binion's for pokwer torunaments), and found a $20 per night rate at the Golden Gate - couldn't refuse.The location is ideal for those on a budget, who do not want to rent a car. You can walk to some good gaming, and lots of cheap eats. The hotel diner is open 24/7, and offers some decent specials - all less than $10. In the evening, Fremont Street comes alive with music, demonstrations and lots of people watching. There are typically 2 bands performing, as well as a solo musician, and overhead rock music video light shows every couple of hours. The hotel was originally built in 1906, and bills itself as the oldest hotel in Las Vegas. While the room furnishings are modern and well maintained, the basic hotel has not changes much - small rooms and bathroom. While the rooms were comfortable, we had two major gripes:1. NO HOT WATER in the mornings. We stayed two nights, tried to take showers between 10 and 11 am, and the water was FREEZING COLD. Water was warm enough to take a decent shower in the evening.2. Too noisy. Housekeeping staff were vacuuming the halls between 7 and 8 am, and woke us up; hallway sounds also carry, and we happened to have some very noisy neighbors.For those complaining about the OUTSIDE noise: the last Fremont Street rock video "light show" typically starts at midnight, and is over by 12:15. By that time, the crowds are all but gone, as have most of the street vendors. If you plan to go to sleep before 12:30, look elsewhere.

Apr 3 2009 	Excellent value fantastic staff.	All good for the price. Bathrooms could use renovation though. New pillow top mattresses, flat screen TV's, etc. The hotel is obviously very dated but that is part of the attraction for some. Valet parking excellent. Would stay again.

Apr 1 2009 	Nice and charming	I stayed at the Golden Gate from the 27-30 March 2009. My husband and I found a deal on the internet for $19 a night and have in the past loved to gamble at this casino so we decided to stay there. We were in Las Vegas to get married that weekend and knew that we would be playing and running around most of the nights with very little sleep and we did not want to spend high dollar to stay on the strip and basically not spend time in our room sleeping so we decided on this hotel.I was pleasantly surprised. I was not expecting a whole lot out of that hotel since it is really old and not really fancy. However, our room had two queen beds, a LARGE flat pannel tv, a closet and a bathroom. The room was really small for two beds and we didnt need the second bed but it faced out on the street towards the Plaza and was quiet. We did not get the noise from Fremont at all.The walls are pretty thin so we could hear the neighbors in the morning when they would get up and leave, but that really could have been because they were noisy. It seemed like all they did was go in and out of their room over and over.The bathroom was the only disappointing part of the hotel. It was very old and not updated in the least with broken tile behind the toilet and the shower curtain seemed a little dirty at the bottom. Our toilet ran all night until we figured out that we just needed to lift the lid (which was too large for the toilet) and set the plunger straight. However, the shower water pressure was perfect! The toiletries were a nice touch but the towels were scratchy.We had a coffee maker in our room and cable television which we only used to get ourselves relaxed to sleep at night but both were sufficient.Maid service was respectable to our hours and we did not see them come and go.Check in was miserable. It took the young guy over thirty minutes to work with the couple in front of us simply because he was extremely slow! Our buddy checked in the next morning and he had a young girl that was fast. Our checkout was extremely fast and the older woman was very friendly!We ate in the cafe several times and their food was really good. We had a thirty minute wait on Friday night because we had a large party (8 of us) but the rest of the time it was no longer than 5-10 minutes at the most and if you wanted to sit at the counter then you were served immediately!They had another open cafe right in the casino floor and it was a HUGE dissapointment. I would NOT eat there again and their service was TERRIBLE. They had a line that was about thirty people deep one evening and TWO people working and it took us over an hour to get our food. GRRRThe floor waitresses that served the craps table were awesome. Totally on top of the drinks. The pit bosses and dealers were a lot of fun as well.I would totally stay there again. I have stayed at the Ritz Carlton in other big cities for $450 per night and the service was not any better than the Golden Gate although their rooms were really nice. However, I am only bringing that up to let you know that i DO know my hotels and motels. The Golden Gate has a charm all of it's own and if you are looking for luxury this place is not for you. However, if you look at it for it's historical charm and the fact that you won't sleep that much anyway in Las Vegas then it is a perfect choice! Besides, we got a STEAL at $19 per night. I probably would have paid up to $70 per night there but no higher and only because of the bathroom. It really was a nasty one. They need to do something with those as soon as possible.My cousin stayed across from us at the Las Vegas Club in a double queen for $80 per night. Her room was twice as large but the beds were HORRIBLE. I even jumped on one and could get NO spring out of it because she said they were hard as a rock and she was absolutely right. I do not think i could have slept there even drunk without pain. The Golden Gate bed we had was heavenly. Extremely comfortable.Stay at the Golden Gate if you get a chance! Small but charming and great service there with excellent food!

Mar 25 2009 	Very Good Room - Great Experience	My room was attractive and newly renovated, but I could not book a non-smoking room online. A very nice touch was windows that really opened and a palm tree right outside my 2nd floor window. Only 12 TV stations, but a nice wide screen TV. Of 106 rooms, 12 are 10 by 10 feet square. Avoid these unless you enjoy the monk experience. The other guests were middle class, middle-aged, multi-racial, pleasant and cheerful.The location is ideal for visiting the low-key downtown Fremont St. area. Valet parking is friendly and efficient. I would return here anytime.

Mar 14 2009 	Golden Gate is great!	I cannot say enough nice things about the staff at the Golden Gate. Helpful, friendly and prompt to the person. The hotel itself is darling. I love how they are owning the historic nature of the property with lots of period touches. The rooms have been re-done in a more contemporary style and they feel plush and cozy, even the little one that I had. The bathrooms have not all been renovated yet; my bathroom still had its original 60's avocado formica, but it was spotless. Rooms are stocked with a coffeemaker, the fixings and neutrogena- a nice upscale touch. The location was great- right at the top of Fremont street. I walked away from my room at the Plaza (which is AWFUL) and booked at the Golden Gate as soon as I saw a room. Again, just impeccable service. You can't beat the promotional rate of $19.06 in commemoration of the hotel opening. I'd pay more. It was a great stay!

Feb 17 2009 	Pleasant Surprises at Bargain Prices	I must have walked past the Golden Gate a 100 times in my day and never even thought of going inside. I needed a cheap room during President's Day weekend and all my usual comp hotels were booked up. I chose the Golden Gate because they offered the cheapest rate in town for that Sunday night, $19.06($21.16 with tax).I requested a double room online and when I checked in I was given room #302 which is right in front on Fremont St, almost on the corner of Main St. I was pleasantly surprised. The decor was beautiful. Have you ever seen a $19 room newly renovated with beautiful dark hardwood furnishings, pillowtop beds, an LCD TV, and clock radio/alarm with an iPod docking station, Neutrogena bath products, coffee maker, etc? Neither have I. All the room needed was a fridge to be in line with many 4 star hotel rooms I've stayed in. Beds: The pillowtop beds were extra comfy with high TC sheets. I'm 5'11" and 240lbs and they were not too short as another reviewer stated. Other than the noise outside I slept very well.Floor Space: Before I left for Vegas, after what I read here, I told my massage therapist that we would have to wait til the next night at Main Steeet Station for my massage. Wrong. My room had plenty of space for a massage table. In fact, I could have held a cocktail party with 10-12 adults in #302 quite comfortably. There's plenty of room, unlike what has been written here in other reviews.Bathroom: Now here is where we drift off. Most guys wont mind the lack of counter top and shelf space but most females will be highly annoyed. The old fashioned shower worked very well with plenty of water pressure and hot water, almost like an aqua massage. The Neutrogena toiletries were a nice touch too. Plenty of towels furnished in all sizes.Closet: there is a huge walk in closet, very deep with a rack of hangers in the middle. Very strange. I would add to the bathroom space with some of this wasted space.Noise: the room had three windows that open directly onto Fremont Street. This is great unless you actually plan to sleep at some point before 7am. The Fremont Street Experience goes on til midnight, but the drunks stay up til 4am hooting, hollering and screaming. Then about 5am, all the service vehicles start their day; trash trucks, street sweepers and cleaners, delivery trucks, etc. Ear plugs don't help much. It's like being on Bourbon St during Mardi Gras. If you like noise and action, request a room between #301-#310. If not, ask for a quieter room location.Casino: The casino is small with not much to offer. I did enjoy playing Viva Las Vegas video slots with Elvis and Ann Margaret. I won $120 in a bonus round and headed across the street to Las Vegas Club where I was served only too well by beautiful young co ed types. Drink service was dismal at Golden Gate. Also, there's plenty of staff hanging around but they don't seem to do much but block the aisles. Some of my fellow patrons had this down as well.Food: I didn't try any of the cuisine here but the ambiance looked quite nice. Very relaxed with warm hardwood decor.Bottom line: I wouldn't hesitate to stay here again or to recommend Golden Gate to others. The benefits far outweigh any downsides. The location is excellent for a downtown trip.Notes:Parking is valet only directly behind the hotel off Main St.Elevator service is adequate and stairs are an option.Lots of memories in those walls but no ghosts. Sorry. I asked a couple of them for comments but they refused.

Feb 8 2009 	Good stay @ the Golden Gate!	This was my second stay @ the Golden Gate, my first stay having been in November of 2008. The rooms were renovated last summer & have an art deco look to them. It was clean & everything worked. They are on the small side, but that didn't matter to me since I was traveling by myself. The windows pop open to the outside, which was kind of neat. The mattresses are very comfortable & I slept very well. I was in room 314, above the alley, with Fremont St. to the north. Because of potential noise, I wore earplugs when I slept. I'm glad to say they worked very well, I didn't hear any noise from the alley or other rooms. However, don't stay here if you plan on going to bed before the FSE shows end at midnight, because you'll hear it, earplugs or not. Since I don't got to bed that early, it wasn't an issue for me. The only noise from the alley was an occasional delivery truck, and that was usually in mid-afternoon. Overall, I'd easily stay here again, especially since they give me 5 night comps every quarter! I like gambling in their casino & a little craps & VP action insures that the offers keep on coming.

Feb 6 2009 	Oh well	This was probably the smallest room that I ever stayed in.I was in Vegas for the superbowl,so who cares?The walls are paper thin,could hear conversations in the next room and hallway.Rooms were clean and nicely decorated.Usually don't spend much time in the room when in vegas,but this weekend I got sick and spent much time there.TV only had a few channels.Gladly my room was facing Main Street so was pretty quiet.Room was a comp so I guess I shouldn't complain.Don't think that I would pay for a room in this hotel,but for free it was great.

Nov 29 2008 	like being in prison	i recently stayed at golden gate. it was my most miserable stay in vegas ive ever had.first the room was the smallest room ive ever stayed in with the view looking at a wall. no heat in the room,no controlled air condition,construction noise from 6:30am till dark-good luck trying to sleep.only 12 tv channels for those who do like to spend a little time in there room.the shower would go hot to cold to hot for the time in the shower.please dont waste your time or money staying at this hotel. very claustraphobic.will never stay there again or recomend it to anyone.

Sep 14 2008 	Nice Hotel	Family of five from UK touring Nevada. We stayed one night here and were a bit concerned having read some reviews. I cannot believe complaints of room size - they were enormous. Brilliant location opposite Freemont Street which is noisy until midnight.The rooms were clean and any criticism would be that the corridors need renovating - but we didn't sleep in the corridor! The staff were very helpful and friendly and this was the first we had encountered valet parking.Plenty to do in the area and plenty of places to eat. Prices for everything are a lot cheaper than the other end of the Strip. If we get back to Las Vegas we will stay here again. It isn't five star but we never booked five star and we found this to be very good value for money.

Aug 26 2008 	I liked it but women may not.	I stayed at the Golden Gate Aug 22-23 2008. My roomrate was cheaper over the phone than the internet, I paid $65 a night.After reading other reviews, I wasn't sure what to expect at the Golden Gate. Some say this place is a dump, others say it is very clean, I found my room to be clean.As advised, I requested a 4th floor room, but was told someone activated the sprinklers a few days earlier so the 2nd floor was closed & were short on rooms. I was given room 306 facing Fremont St.I got a kick out of the view from my room, the windows opened right out to Fremont St., we had a great view of the Thunderdome cage too. Nice if youre in Vegas to have fun all night, but if you plan to do a lot of sleeping, the Fremont Experience is easily seen and heard in this Hotel.The bathroom was just OK, it could have been better, but seemed to bug the girl I was with more than myself, and the air conditioning couldn't keep up until the mornings.On Friday, they had $3 blackjack, but Saturday, the price went up to $5, at least they added bikini table dancers to compensate.I joined the Player's club to get the 99 cent shrimp cocktail, and was able to milk some free cards, dice and calendar just by asking at signup.I ate twice at the Bay City Diner, the food was good, but the prices were kind of high. I do recommend their signature burger with the knife stabbed through it, and the deep fried spaghetti.I will probably stay here again, while the casino floor was nicely remodeled, the bathrooms & air conditioning could use some work.

Jul 30 2008 	stay somewhere else	I have been visiting the Golden Gate casino for several years, they offered me a 4 night free stay, I read some of the reviews but said what the heck, I'll give it a try. The next morning I opened the drapes and saw the filth everywhere.... the floors, the dresser, the walls!! I immediately packed my things and went to the elevator, where I found a bloody bandage on the floor! I checked out immediately, interestingly the desk person didn't even question my quick exit! Jul 17 2008 	Hotel ok dining = horrid	The hotel? Well, it was okay. Small rooms, but great access to the super cool Fremont street (where the light's show and live music make for wonderful ambience). The Fremont area is much more low-key than the strip, and proivded enjoyable atmosphere and good drink specials ;). However, I must caution one and all about the hotel's "Bay City Diner." Jul 3 2008 	The Best of Classic Las Vegas!	Readers, the Golden Gate is a fun hotel! It is right in the middle of the Fremont Street action, and the staff members are friendly. Here is the summary of my 18-20 June, 2008 visit:The associates at the Front Desk were pleased to check me in early, to Room #402. They were friendly and helpful.I see no particular reason for the $20 bill trick at the Golden Gate. Remember, you try to get something specific, like "View of the pool" or "under the Fremont Street canopy".The rooms are very small, yes. You must know this before you reserve here. This is vintage Vegas, and very tall/very heavy visitors would not be happy in the room I had. To me, the spartan surroundings are part of the charm.There were two live piano players during my visit: the "Bandit Pianist" (careful when you say that) and an older lady. Both were superb, and the piano provided an Old West atmosphere that you will not see anywhere else.I saw $3 blackjack throughout my visit, any time of day or night. Here's a good way to stretch those funds.The food service was very good. Get your "Club 1906" card in order to buy the classic shrimp cocktail for 99 cents. The Bay City Diner had excellent breakfasts.Parking is on a flat lot, with no shade. Valet is required, so there is a $1-$3 tip needed for each driving trip. The valets will crank your AC, so this worked better than I thought.Room AC and facilities were fine. The AC blanked out the ground noise from the bus stop at the Plaza across the street. if you are a light sleeper, ask for a 4th-floor room.My room rate was $30 per night, from one of the online sites. This was weeknights in June. This price was terrific!Vintage Vegas photos and art are plentiful; you can see action shots of the Rat Pack, Casino(the movie), Pay it Forward(the movie), CSI, and art with a San Francisco theme.I will visit again! Congratulations, GG staff!Readers can ask for more info atDrGPadgett@ms.metrocast.netby entering the subject line "Las Vegas".Regards,Gene Padgett!Starkville, MSI will return to the Golden Gate.

Jun 5 2008 	Affordable Downtown Hotel without the frills	Golden Gate Hotel is THE original downtown hotel and casino. Located at the very top of the Freemont Experience , this quaint little hotel has a lot going for it.Firstly its cheap. The rooms are small, but we found the beds comftable and the rooms clean. We have stayed there a few times. The bathrooms are tiny, with little room to move around in, but for the price, you really cant expect too much.Inside the hotel there are two places to eat. The Shrimp Bar and Deli, located near reception, has a variety of sandwiches, soup and other cafeterria style eats. The real attraction here is the 99c Shrimp Cocktail (only 99c to Club 1906 members, the hotel's Rewards Programme, which is free to join, so go on and do it!) The story behind the Cocktail is that in 1959, the Golden Gate introduced the Shrimp Cocktail and it's been voted Best of Las Vegas for years since! Worth the 99c just to say you've tried it!!The other eatery in the hotel is the Bay City Diner, which is located around the back of the casino. We actually missed it the first time around, but are glad we eventually found it. The meals are HUGE and the prices are really reasonable. The place is one of our favourite places to eat downtown...its not fancy, just good food at reasonable prices (and they are open till really late!)This hotel is great for people who wont spend too much time in their rooms (ie, poker players or any hardcore gambler hahaha). We did experience some loud neighbours on our last visit, the walls dont seem to be very thick, so that was a negative. The other negative is the check -in policy they have. You cant check in till some ridiculous time...I think its 12pm, so if you're plane arrives at 7am, you have to wonder the streets! (well, they did allow us to leave our luggage in their store room, but it was just really inconvenient)I think its well-worth the stay if its short.

Apr 25 2008	paper thinwalls	Unless you want to hear your neighbor going to the bathroom, and love the fact that when you take a shower the water goes from hot (extremely hot) to cold, oh and want to have the lopsided bed with stains, and the lovely view of a brick wall, then this is the place for you. We were there with friends and the rooms were about 9 X 9 including the bathroom. Our rooms were right next to eachother so when i hopped in the shower i heard our friends talking, yes talking, and clearly! so while i was taking a shower i was talking with our friends right next door, i wasnt using the phone either. the best description of this room: prison. Apr 15 2008 	Relaxing and Charming for a small spot	I had read the previous reviews and still decided to stay there. I was completely content with my decision. The place was magnificent. Apr 15 2008	Keep Coming Back	I stayed at the Golden Gate for New Years. I have stayed at this hotels countless times. Staff and check in are super friendly. Normally Geri or Debbie (mother and daughter) are there. They are the nicest people. MAKE SURE YOU ASK FOR A ROOM ON THE 4TH FLOOR. Otherwise you will be in very tiny rooms. Most double rooms have twin beds. You get 2 queen size beds on the 4th floor. Rooms are much bigger then the rooms downstairs. Everything is really old fashioned. This hotel is for people that just need a place to sleep. If you plan on lounging in your room, stay somewhere else! You do get a coffee maker and a there is a small t.v. in the room (not many channels). There is no pool. This is just a hotel. They are really good at comping rooms. They have gone with the player cards now. I was able to get comped a 2 night stay and I really didn't play that much. Slots are very tight! People do better on the tables. Cocktail service is not very good if your playing slots. Most waitress stay by the tables. Casino is really small, but some how its takes 15 min to get a drink. They have 2 places to eat: Bay City Diner and the snack bar. Food is very bland, but prices are cheap. They offer good specials late at night and early morning. Breakfast is the best pick. I visit Vegas very often and have stayed at many hotels. Please feel free to contact me with any questions.

Nov 13 2006 	Could have done better	We wanted to stay downtown and have stayed at some of the other properties and thought we would give the Golden Gate a try. Not only to they promote themselves as the smallest casino/hotel in Vegas but they have been around for 100 years. The history of the hotel was a good reason for me to check it out.I had read some reviews here at Trip Advisor prior to our stay but they varied so greatly from one to the next which made it hard to decide.The hotel itself on the outside looks clean and nice, there are nice frosted glass doors with brass and wood trim. The windows have little flower boxes outside of them - very inviting.The inside, casino and hotel check in is very old fashioned looking. They have some old slot machines on display, the wood walls, etcl all looks very nice and reminds you of what it must have been like years ago.The room was very small like a lot of the other reviews have mentioned, they use older looking fixtures in the room, the doors are all wood and the one to the closet is really small. The bathroom door hits the toilet when you open the door, very cramped and small. If you have ever been in a standard stateroom on a cruise ship it is a lot like that but not as clean.The staff is very friendly and security often patrols the hallways of the hotel. The building is only 4 stories with the first story being the casino and diner. There are 106 rooms total.We stayed in room 121. We apparently were right above the maintenance department as we could hear the roll up door at all hours. It was noisy, the windows were drafty, we faced an alley and at 10 PM on a Saturday the garbage truck came and dumped the dumpsters, it was so loud. We also had the soda vending machine next to our wall and heard it every 15 minutes or so hum in intervals. The vending machine stopped taking money at one point so I went to the other floors and not one vending machine was working. We informed the front desk but the situation was never fixed. Also if you are traveling with small children you may want to reconsider - the windows open completely and there are no screens. The bed spreads felt nasty like they had dirt or film of some sort substance on them. Underneath the night stand I could see trash, not sure what it was but I wasn't going to stick my hand under there. You could see dirt on the walls that I felt should have been cleaned each time. The grout in the bathroom was dingy and you could see the sloppy repairs they had made to the wall when they had a plumbing leak. The toilet reminded me of a public restroom toilet, had the kick lever to flush. The plug outlet in the bathroom is only one outlet with the other being the light switch. The outlet is mounted upside down so if you have a hair dryer or razor that has the bulkier plug you can't plug it in, your only other plug is under the dresser on a power strip.The old place has a lot of history and I think that if they would take the time to remodel the rooms like they did downstairs in the diner and casino they would be a great gem in downtown.

Nov 4 2006 	Vintage Vegas	First off you have to stop and look at what the hotel is. Vintage, historic and original. Yes, it is old and that is part of the charm. We just returned from Vegas and a stay at the Golden Gate. We found the hotel to be very clean. The rooms are small, but very clean. The bathroom is small and room for two, if you like the person you are with. The decore is as it was years ago. If you are interested in the past, this is where you need to stay. When this hotel was built, it was the top of the line. This is one of the few places that does not feel the need to keep up with the Wynns and Boyds. If you are looking for history, walk around and look at the photos on the walls and the old slot machines in the back corners. The service was excellent, the registration desk, house keeping, dealers, cocktails waitresses. All were pleasant and always had a smile and kind word. I have never stayed at another Vegas hotel and recieved a morning paper at my door. Never had so many staff memebers asking if we were enjoying our stay and if there was anything that they could do for us. If your hungry, you do not have to go far. The Bay City Diner is a great little hole in the wall. The food is great and the prices are even better. The Shrimp cocktail for $.99 is a great snack or mini meal at the deli. They also have great sanwiches which are more than filling. Will I stay here again? YES! Will I recomend it to friends? Only the ones that can appreciate the history

Nov 7 2005	Great for travellers but not tourists	If you relish unique travel experiences (ie a real traveller) then you will love the Golden Gate. May 22 2005	Decent for 1st time to Vegas...but read on...	Just spent my first week in Vegas and all I can say is...WOW!!!! But this is about the hotel so here's my reveiw. First off, this is what I did.... do your research before staying in Vegas. If you're "rich" or can afford to stay in a fancy hotel, or are really picky about having a big room, or being right on the Strip... well, this hotel is not for you. The room was fine--small, about the size of a budget inn hotel. Water pressure really good!!! (That's important to me when I'm taking a shower!) The only thing I didn't like is that the rooms don't have mini refrigerators in them. I would have liked to have some cold drinks on hot days. (The soda machine is down the hall, and it only cost a dollar.)  Very casual place... gambling was fun downstairs, and is perfect for the first-timer gambler (like myself!). Don't miss the famous 99 cent shrimp cocktails at the deli...great deal...the other food I would give 3 out of 5, and prices were average... You get MUCH better deals at the buffet at the hotels on the strip. I wish they had more employee help behind the counter at times... you can sometimes wait a LONG time just for a shrimp cocktail. I think the parking can be improved too.... it's a small lot next to the hotel, and it's supposed to be free...BUT they have "valet" service for insurance purposes. So even if you see your car right in front of you, you have to hand over your ticket and have the guy drive it for you and then tip him a dollar, which I thought was stupid. HOWEVER...a dollar for parking is perfectly fine on Fremont street....(**on the Strip, ALL HOTELS HAVE FREE SELF-PARKING) The location is average... you're right on the Fremont Street experience which is loads of fun and something to experience....but it is NOT within walking distance of the Strip. And you don't want to wander off Fremont Street because the surroundings have a bad reputation and is dangerous. My recommendations: A family vacation--don't stay here....look into the Strip, or the Rio or Palms hotel. It is perfectly fine for a first-timer couple who is still iffy on spending alot on a room.... I HIGHLY RECOMMEND renting a car, it was a really good decision!!! (I used my BJs wholesale club and got a discount on an Avis car rental) I didn't have to worry about taking a bus or cab every day to the strip...AND...we got to drive to Lake Mead and Hoover Dam.... forget about the bus and helicopter tours... drive there yourself! Las Vegas was awesome!!! I will go back next year, but I won't be staying at the Golden Gate. It was perfectly fine for the first-timer, but next year I'll consider something on the Strip itself.  Hope my review was helpful, and have lots of luck in Vegas!

Jun 11 2009 	Brand New Hotel / Employees Show Pride	Layout is typical Hampton Inn - but the newness shows everywhere from the sparkling floors in the lobby

Great hotel friendly dealers super price/deal with coupons	Look around the internet and you can find package deals to this hotel for ~$200 for a 4 night stay or 3 night with 6 free buffets. i stayed here because the monorail end here but the place ended up being nice and offering every table game i wanted, i never left!

Absolutely Stunning	The Hilton Grand Vacation Club at the Las Vegas Strip at 2650 Las Vegas Blvd. is absolutely breathtaking. I stayed for 4 nights and 5 days. The hotel is on the strip and is just a 10-15 minute car drive to the center of the strip, depending on traffic, of course. The hotel is walking distance to the Sahara, Riviera, Circus-Circus, and the Stratosphere hotels. I would not recommend walking to the heart of the strip from this hotel. Its too far.The Deuce bus will take you up and down the strip unlimited times for $7 a day or simply having a rental car works well. The monorail can be picked up from across the street at the Sahara Hotel. The station is located to the back of the hotel through the casino.They are building a humongous hotel (Vdara Hotel and Spa) and a mall across the street but that may take a while to complete. A handy CVS is located right next door and a McDonalds, Subway, and Nathans Pizza are located at the Circus-Cirucs Hotel.Parking- the parking structure is a short trek to the back of the hotel but for $5 more ($13 a day) you can have valet parking and relax in the hotel lobby until your car arrives. Regular parking is $8 per day.Bathroom- from Kohler toilets and sinks to elegant Baltic green granite countertops to an all tile shower with plenty of room for 2. I stayed in Tower 2 the slightly newer tower than tower 1. I found out that the difference between the 2 towers is that tower 1 has a jetted tub in the bathroom while tower 2 has a soaker tub and no balconies.Kitchen- Very well designed with raised full outlay, cherry kitchen cabinets and the same rich, elegant light-colored Baltic green granite countertops. A full kitchen with a full size refrigerator, oven, microwave, washer/ dryer combo, dishwasher, coffee maker, blender, and toaster are standard. Again, there is a Kohler kitchen sink and all the appliances are made by Cuisinart.Room- I had a 1-bedroom suite that had a separate king-size bed, which connected to the bathroom via a sliding door. The bed was extremely comfortable and the room had a large TV, lounge chair, and a full size mirror attached to the back of the door.Living Room- comfortable sofa and lounge chair with a flat screen TV. The sofa doubles as a full size bed that is also very comfortable and not just for kids but adults too.Dining room- a beautiful glass table with 4 chairs.Desk- a laptop nook is also nice BUT the high speed internet that is suppose to be complimentary simply sucks. I never really got a strong connection and never could surf the internet. I even had them bring me an Ethernet cable that did nothing. The girl at the front desk told me they are working on adding more data ports but that she also agreed that the high-speed wireless internet is not great.There is a big 24-hour fitness gym with free weights, treadmill and an elliptical. There is also a 24-hour game room with a pool table, big screen TV, and table tennis. There is also a Starbucks coffee shop and a small convenience store all on the first floor

Nov 22 2009 	Hilton Grand Vacation Resort	Suites are all fitted with washer/dryer, dishwasher, coffee maker, fridge/freezer and all other kitchen appliances. Separate bath from shower, 2 TVs and lounge area. No Casino here so a quiet haven to return to at the end of a hectic day on the strip.

Nov 18 2009 	If you like fancy 	I have stayed here several times in the past year. A very new property and part of the Hilton Grand Vacations group. The rooms are very clean & super comfortable. Nov 17 2009 	Loved it!	We are owners of HGV and reside in California. (Worth mentioning, this is not a hotel or motel. Nov 16 2009 	Great Experience Quiet place to stay in Las Vegas	We stayed here Thursday - Sunday & thoroughly enjoyed it. We were in a one-bedroom suite. The place was immaculate! Oct 24 2009 	Beauiful spacious clean room. Lots of amenities.	We own at the HGVC Flamingo and used points to book this mid-week M-Th getaway.Owners get complimentary parking (garage level 4 and up), internet (LAN & wi-fi), and use of the fitness center.Fitness center - about 10 treadmills, step climber and a few ellipticals. We had a 3-bedroom (2 br + the lockoff unit). The 3-br units are all on floors 36-39 (top floor). We were in Tower 2, the northeastern tower (more North-South view oriented), which had a nice view of the strip (saw PH Westgate, MGM, Mandalay Bay, and then west to the Rio & Palms), but the main part of the strip was blocked by the tower on the adjacent property to the south. We could see the north view from the elevator area windows and that looked very nice as well - not blocked by anything.Interior: Granite countertops throughout. Master bath in the 2 br had a very nice touch - the spa-shower where you not only had the regular shower head, but 3 additional nozzles at chest, abdomen, and thigh-level. Living area had a pull-out. You can get groceries a couple miles away to the east or west at supermarkets, and there is a Whole Foods at the new Town Square mall south of the strip.Service - like other vacation ownership locations, less-than-weekly stays do not get maid service, though you can ask for more towels or sheets to change out yourself. Oct 15 2009 	Beautiful Retreat	My husband and I were here for a timeshare demonstration. We went into it basically for a "free" anniversary place to go since funds are tight. After reading some of the reviews before we left, I was very scared although a friend of mine had just been to the new one in Orlando and loved it. It is a beautiful hotel and the staff couldn't be more attentive and helpful. We stayed in tower two in a one-room suite and it was large with a full kitchen/laundry, dining room, livingroom with flat-screen t.v. with Bose sound system, king-size bedroom with a two-person tub right next to it and another flat-screen t.v., and a large bathroom with granite/marble countertops. Although upon arrival, the maintenance guy was fixing the dishwasher, he left shortly after we arrived and apologized for not being done already. The bed was very comfortable and it was a treat to travel and have a bed as good as our own (we have a very expensive matress from Ethan Allen and high-end duvet, linens, etc.). I would agree with the reviews that it is at the undesirable end of the strip near all the older hotels (Circus Circus, Sahara, Riveria, etc.), but there is a new one that will be done soon across the street and it looks very high end. Hilton is building two new towers in the near future and there will be a huge new hotel/casino complex between this hotel and Circus Circus once the economy turns around. It was nice to know that not every "Joe Schmoe" off the strip can walk into the hotel and as one reviewer noted, they will/may check to see that you have a room key later into the night (which I did not mind at all). We didn't get to spend much time at the pool, but when we did, it was as big as other larger casinos I've stayed (Treasure Island, Rio, MGM, New York/New York). Prices for snack items/food were high inside the hotel, but there is a CVS next door (although their prices weren't much better). If I were to stay here again and if we stayed a week instead of 3 days/2 nights, I would go get some groceries and utilize the kitchen a little more (at least for breakfast and lunch)...although I don't think you should have to cook on vacation...especially in the land of buffets! Note: DO NOT got to the buffet at Sahara...I wouldn't feed my dog the stuff they had there and it smelled! Overall--the Hilton Grand Vacation Club is great for couples wanting to gamble a little (easy walk or bus/tram), get away from it all and get great airfare and great weather. For going to the timeshare demo, we received $50 to be used at the Hilton Convention Center just east of our hotel (easy walk...but not in high heels) and ate at T.J. Steakhouse. My husband's filet mignon was the best he ever ate.

Oct 14 2009 	Good non-gaming hotel a top end of strip	First thing to bear in mind that this is a timeshare resort which means the rooms will come fully equipped for catering etc which in general , all things are provided . Being a non-gaming hotel it can be an oasis of calm to return to and general impressions are quite good ,in between the Riveria and Sahara area of the strip , its housed in two towers of about 25 levels each which i believe differ slightly but you enter via the main door and the atmosphere is rather low key with reception at the same level with a very handy mini-market , deli-counter where they make up rolls etc and fresh coffee which is open from 5am to 1am next day downstairs so if you don"t want o do it yourself , you can wander down here . There is an outdoor swimming pool , a tour desk, but thats it so because of its timeshare status , some people may find it limited .The rooms are a very good size with a fully eqipped kitchinette , fridge/freezer , washer & dryer , good size seating area with dining table & chairs , tv and of course , air-con .The bathroom has a shower , toilet and washbasin and the bedroom houses a spa-type bath along with plenty of storage space , in general eveything seemed to be of a good standard .You are not stuck for transport as there are plenty of taxis always to hand , a bus stop for the "deuce" service right outside and the Monorail at The Sahara is only a 5-8 minute walk away also there is a CVS pharmacy store next door - which sells more than just medicine -along with other shops just a few more moments away . Overall , not a bad stay the only main drawbacks being that i would find it hard to recommend if you have children and the locaton - there is a large amount of development going on around the area which is not eye pleasing also creating large areas of wasteland to walk past which also sadly seems to attract vagrants which can be annoying and the last thing - if Vegas is busy , it can take forever to get around.Apart from that , this hotel is not too bad at all if you like low-key activites just a shame its not a little closer to the action

Oct 8 2009 	great place to stay - no casino = no smoke!	this hotel is at the north end on the strip so the trafic there is much better. the rooms are huge and look nice, sep.jet tub, big shower, nice full kitchen. hotel very clean, housekeeping could use a little more detail. no casino at the hotel (lots next door and around), i hate smoke and can't stand walking through casinos to get to buffets and shows so this is definately the place i want to stay next time i go visit.. if you work out or do cardio, the gym is to die for! top of the line equipment, anything you can imagine. next to the gym there is a game room which is very awsome too. pool table, big screen tv with sofas, fooseball, ping-pong table, games etc. the pool is laso very nice. so overall the perfect place if you want quiet, the rooms are well sealed, walls are thick. they are building two more towers in the future so it has an empty lot next to it but they didn't start on it yet (as of sept. 09). also go see some cirque du soleil shows they are the best! have fun, i hope i helped a little chosing.

Sep 28 2009 	A Wonderful Surprise on the Las Vegas Strip	I have been to Las Vegas countless times - always staying at the big resorts on The Strip, but often trying different properties for variety.
